item.title: Browse WSL Path in Windows Explorer
item.description: Open Windows explorer and type this in address bar 1\\wsl$ See details in this article

item.title: NodeJS Install in WSL
item.description: NodeJS 14+ is needed in WSL. Usual installation via apt in Ubuntu doesn't work. This one works so far: 1curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_16.x | sudo -E bash - 2sudo apt-get install -y nodejs

item.title: Check Windows Uptime
item.description: Sometimes, you need to check the uptime of a Windows machine. Here's the Powershell command for that: 1PS C:\> systeminfo|find "System Boot Time" This was tested working under Windows 10 Pro and worth noting that it also works in the old cmd. For other methods, see this article.

item.title: Reboot Linux under WSL
item.description: Linux systemcmd or init way of rebooting will not work in a Windows Subsystem for Linux or wsl-run Linux. You need to use the Powershell command below: 1wsl --shutdown For other methods, see this article.

item.title: Fix Garbage in Windows Japanese Locale
item.description: If you see garbage characters instead of the expected non-English language, fix is easy. Install corresponding language pack (Japanese in this case) https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/language-packs-for-windows-a5094319-a92d-18de-5b53-1cfc697cfca8 Set the locale for non-unicode programs. See https://www.digitalcitizen.life/changing-display-language-used-non-unicode-programs/

item.title: Check if Windows is 64-bit Using Powershell
item.description: 1PS C:\> [Environment]::Is64BitProcess 2PS C:\> [Environment]::Is64BitOperatingSystem both will return "True" if you're on a 64 bit Windows. See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31977657/determining-32-64-bit-in-powershell
